qas.question: What is one city with an accumulation of secular Gothic structures?
What is another city with an accumulation of secular Gothic structures?
What style are most windows on secular Gothic structures?
Where are pointed arches and vaulted ceilings found on most secular Gothic structures?
What is the name of the surviving monastic building in England?
What is the only city with an accumulation of secular Gothic structures?
What style are all windows on secular Gothic structures?
Where are pointed arches and vaulted ceilings concealed on most secular Gothic structures?
What is the name of the surviving monastic building in Egypt?

context: Other cities with a concentration of secular Gothic include <a0_0><b5_0>Bruges<b5_0/><a0_0/> and <a1_0>Siena<a1_0/>. Most surviving small secular buildings are relatively plain and straightforward; most windows are <a2_0><b6_0>flat-topped with mullions<b6_0/><a2_0/>, with pointed arches and vaulted ceilings often only found at <a3_0><b7_0>a few focal points<b7_0/><a3_0/>. The country-houses of the nobility were slow to abandon the appearance of being a castle, even in parts of Europe, like England, where defence had ceased to be a real concern. The living and working parts of many monastic buildings survive, for example at <a4_0><b8_0>Mont Saint-Michel<b8_0/><a4_0/>.
